ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A great class. The course readings are extremely interesting, and Prof. Weir leads incredibly engaging discussions in seminar. Her extensive experience doing research in Northern Ireland brings a really interesting perspective to the course. The course is not too much work - weekly summaries on all readings, one presentation, and a final paper. Definitely recommend taking a course with Prof. Weir.
No, definitely not. Class lacked structure and the seminar seemed to be lead more by the students than the teacher.

Summary: A great survey of civil conflict, its influences, and its implications. The reading load is what you might expect from a political science seminar, but it's usually relevant and pretty interesting. I would highly recommend it to others.
Good class! Final paper was fun - very open-ended will allow you to pick a topic you are passionate about. It was helpful to use the troubles as a central case.

Good class - lots of interesting material. I would recommend it if you have some background in Civil Conflict and want a more academic-literature oriented course. And there's a nice innovation of a final paper discussion - sort of like an academic conference. Prof. Weir is also really cool as a person, tells great stories - my only wish is that reading presentations in class were shortened, because we already had summaries of the readings to do.

This is a great seminar -- thorough, rigorous, and taught by an excellent professor. The first half of the course is a broad, discipline-level survey of major questions in civil-war studies, including a lot of wonderful classic readings; the second is a focused case study of the conflict in Northern Ireland. Readings are generally manageable but can be up to a (long) book a week, with additional weekly response requirements; there's also one final paper and an in-class presentation on a reading of the student's choice. Overall, very highly recommended, especially for those with some background in security/conflict studies who are looking to read a little more deeply.
